result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Repeater] and Operating w/ PAC (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Repeater]. The defendant was found guilty of OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Repeater] and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Repeater] was dismissed by the court.

  • Pedro T. Winfrey was found guilty of OWI (4th w/in 5 yrs) [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Pedro T. Winfrey was found guilty of Possession of Cocaine/Coca(2nd+), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(c).
  • Pedro T. Winfrey was found guilty of Possession of THC (2nd+ Offense), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes:
The Defendant is to undergo any counseling the agent finds appropriate and must comply with any recommended treatment/assessment/counseling.
  The Defendant is to complete AODA assessment and comply with any treatment recommended.
  The Defendant is to maintain absolute sobriety - no alcohol or drugs unless prescribed by a physician.
  The Defendant is to obtain and maintain full time employment and/or educational programming as recommended.
  The Defendant is not to go into any bars, taverns or businesses where the primary purpose is to sell alcohol.
